results.title: Japan: a banquet menu
results.creator_credit: Hal Weiner, Marilyn Weiner and Screenscope
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World of Cooking”.
Shows chef Nobuo Iida and his assistants preparing and presenting a traditional Japanese banquet. Highlights the importance of custom and ritual in Japanese cooking.

results.title: Japan newly discovered
results.creator_credit: Japan. National Tourist Organisation and Dentsu
results.brief_description: Japan has been influenced by many countries, and today alternate layers of traditional and foreign cultures appear like the rings of a tree. We see this pattern in the ageless architectural beauty of the Shinto and Buddhist shrines and temples, and the later Christian churches; in the ancient castles, palaces and homes contrasting with the modern concrete and steel skyscrapers; and in the arts and crafts - the tea ceremony, formal gardens, pottery and embroidery.

results.title: Japan nearby
results.brief_description: A young woman doing research for her thesis on Japan - Australia Relations and a young man interested in architecture, share some of their knowledge and ideas with the audience while showing them aspects of traditional and modern Japanese life both in Australia and Japan.

results.title: Japan invades China: crisis in the Far East
results.creator_credit: Anthony Potter, Michael D. Ornstein and Alan Landsburg Productions
results.brief_description: Shows how Japan, encouraged by lack of Western resistance took control of French Indochina, the Dutch Indies, Burma, Malaya and the Philippines. Roosevelt attempted to counter Japan’s escalating aggression, and by mid-1941, a total embargo was enforced and all assets originating in Japan were frozen on the market. In the face of this pressure, the Japanese government forced the United States into war. Narrated by Eric Sevareid. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Japan inc: lessons for North America?
results.creator_credit: Kalle Lasn, Peter Jones, John Coney, John Taylor and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Organization, discipline and productivity in Japan are on a scale not known in any other country of the world. For the 110 million people of Japan, survival means doing things together—a concept that has seen that nation automate and computerize at an unparalleled rate. Just how this level of achievement was reached is the subject of this absorbing documentary study of Japanese business and industry.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kalle Lasn, Peter Jones, John Coney, John Taylor and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Japan in winter
results.brief_description: Japan in winter is a busy time of the year with preparations for the celebration of the New Year (Japan’s equivalent of Christmas time). This is the time when the most colorful festivals take place all over the country and the people make great preparations for the ceremonies. On New Year’s Day the shrines and streets are crowded as millions of Japanese take part in winter celebrations.

results.title: Japan behind the mask: a special report by John Pilger
results.brief_description: John Pilger presents a two-part look at the “real” Japan, at working and living conditions, at education, the status of women and at nationalism. Pilger demonstrates that behind the public relations image of a high tech, happy population, employed for life by benevolent big brother companies, lies the private truth of powerless unions, small companies, unemployment, inequality between the sexes, pollution, educational pressure and escalating expenditure on armaments. Yet in spite of all this, the everyday kindness, modesty and grace of the Japanese people is unaffected.

results.title: Japan - Land of the Rising Sun
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Travellers’ guide to the Orient”.
Part 1: Tokyo and Yokohama - In Tokyo, one of the largest cities in the world, Japan’s traditional past mixes with the streamlined present. The bustling sophistication of the Ginza, with its renowned department stores and shopping, contrast with the historic Imperial Palace. Yokohama has a famous harbour and colourful history. Yokohama’s many attractions include its historic Chinatown, the Marine Tower, the beautiful Sankeien Gardens, and the amazing City of Tomorrow. Part 2: Kyoto, Hakone, Okayame and Kanazawa. Japan’s former capital, the ancient city of Kyoto with its palaces, wonderful temples and delightful parks is full of charm. Famed Gion Corner with its introduction to Japanese arts and theatre and the talent of the Geisha. Visit the Heian Shrine to see a Japanese wedding and contemplate the stunning Golden Pavilion of the Kinkakuji Temple. History and beauty combine to greet twenty million visitors to Hakone’s many attractions include the celebrated Open Air Museum. Okayama, Kurashiki and Kanazawa have many attractions to offer including castles, museums, beautiful gardens and markets and arts and crafts. Rated: G

results.title: Japan's surrender
results.brief_description: Documentary profiling the USA’s victory over Japan through atomic warfare during World War II and their eventual surrender signifying the end of the War. Edited by Eugene W. Castle.
